page.title: 01S.Tyne Centred On Dilston
page.content: A rural area mainly of sandstone with poor soil rising to 191 metres. Just under one quarter is coniferous plantations with roedeer red squirrels badgers, foxes, rabbits, large anthrills. The scattered mixed farms are old family-owned with large barns for fodder for the long winters. Although built of local sandstone they have been re-roofed in slate. Interconnecting lanes are lined wuth dry stone walls and /or remnants of old deciduous woodland. The ruined castle of Dilston, associated with the Jacobite rebellion, and resident ghost rises from a cliff near picturesque Devil Water. Nearby is a Scouts camping ground. This isolated and sparsely inhabited area gives way in the north to the lower land towards the River Tyne. Here there are good public transport services easily
